thread.title: CU soccer: Buffs nearing desperation time for NCAA bid
thread.title_full: CU soccer: Buffs nearing desperation time for NCAA bid

author:
Pat Rooney 

BuffZone.com Writer
title: CU soccer: Buffs nearing desperation time for NCAA bid
text:
CU soccer: Buffs nearing desperation time for NCAA bid Clock ticking on making postseason push By Pat Rooney 
BuffZone.com Writer Posted: 10/22/2015 05:34:00 PM MDT Colorado's Brittney Stark, center, battles Washington State's Chelsea Harkins for control of the ball during a game earlier this season at Prentup Field. ( Cliff Grassmick / Staff Photographer ) 
University of Colorado soccer coach Danny Sanchez isn't quite ready to call it desperation time just yet. 
That said, his Buffaloes find themselves mired in a frustrating scoring drought while staring at a daunting uphill climb in the Pac-12 Conference race. With five games remaining, CU sits in a tie for 10th place in the league. 
Given the Pac-12 sent nine teams to the NCAA tournament last season, the math is becoming precariously simplistic for the Buffs heading into a weekend trip to Southern California to take on UCLA (Friday) and No. 24 USC (Sunday). 
"We need to get something positive out of the weekend," Sanchez said. "If we focus on playing well, we'll be competitive. We're not looking too far into the future." 
First atop CU's to-do list is solving the mystery of the team's prolonged scoring drought. The Buffs haven't recorded a goal in the run of play since a tally by Brittney Stark in the 40th minute of an eventual overtime win against Cal on Sept. 27. 
Since then, the Buffs have scored a pair of goals off corner kicks and received another last week on an own-goal at Stanford off a free kick. CU has gone roughly 535 minutes without registering a goal in the regular run of play, going 0-4-1 since the win against Cal. 
Still, time hasn't run out yet on the Buffs to control their NCAA tournament fate. At least not yet. Advertisement 
"There's not an easy game. Not in the Pac-12," Sanchez said. "I'm hoping Stanford was an anomaly, because they're not giving up anything to anyone. If we didn't have the personnel, that would be one thing. But we know we have the personnel."
